content: Who exactly should be referred to as a  HODLER? As we already know, hodlers are people who hodl bitcoin for long periods of time; they are determined not to sell for the long term irrespective of the price change.Now here comes my question: If those who buy and hodl their coins on a noncustodial wallet where they have full control over the coin are referred to as hodlers, are those who also hodl under a custodial service where they don’t have full control of the coins also regarded as hodlers?If you leave your coins on a custodial exchange, the exchange is the one holding your coins and not you. What's available in your balance is what they can manually input. Since you don't have full control of the coin, you shouldn't be considered a hodler.Quote from: Synchronice on March 06, 2025, 09:46:31 PMNot your keys, not your coins (and not being a HODLer)Your keys, your coins (and you are HODLer)

What's available in your balance is what they can manually input. Since you don't have full control of the coin, you shouldn't be considered a hodler.When you keep your coins on exchange, you don't have access to them, you just see the numbers, that's all. You can't sign a message, you can't export keys, you can't do anything, so you don't HOLD or HODL coins in this case.You only HODL coins when you have them in your hardware or software wallet, for example you are a HODLer if you own coins on your Electrum wallet, if you own coins on your ColdCard wallet and so on.Not your keys, not your coins (and not being a HODLer)Your keys, your coins (and you are HODLer)

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: Yes. The exchange is the Hodlers (if they haven't used your Bitcoin). Holding means you in charge of your coin And holding through storms for a long time period. Well those keeping their coins in CEX could be called Hodlers But it's not Bitcoin they are holding.

comments.author: Natalim
comments.body: Not your keys, not your coins. If you don’t have the full control over your private keys, then it’s actually not your coins. In short, you don’t own your coins but the exchange holds the full ownership. They are the one hodling your coins, not really you. What you only have is just a piece of paper containing your coins your owned, but in reality the custodial exchange controls everything. If the exchange goes bankrupt and suddenly stop its operation, you could end up losing your access and thus, losing your funds in the exchange.

comments.author: ChiBitCTy

Yeah it absolutely stupid to hold your coins at an exchange, but if you're not selling you're still in possession of the bitcoin (until Conbase decides to freeze your account.

comments.author: SatoPrincess
comments.body: Anyone who is serious about hodling bitcoin for long term should understand how to store bitcoin and the difference between exchanges and non-custodial wallets. Hodling your coins in an exchange is like gambling because you cannot be sure of the result. A hack might happen and you will lose your coins or the exchange might restrict your account for some reason or they could declare bankruptcy. There is a lot of ‘what if’s’ that comes with storing your bitcoins in CEXs. Quote from: Ambatman on March 06, 2025, 09:51:11 PMWell those keeping their coins in CEX could be called Hodlers But it's not Bitcoin they are holding. What are they hodling then?

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: Quote from: Nwada001 on March 06, 2025, 10:00:21 PMWhat exactly are they holding that they should be called Hodlers? A share of the exchange holdings.

comments.author: batang_bitcoin
comments.body: Holding in exchanges means that you're still holding but your money is at risk but technically as what is trying to say, is that you're not holding your own money but someone holds it for you and that's the risk in there. While holding it with the wallet that we hold the keys, there's the peace of mind and we can be proud to be called actual holders. But this shouldn't be a debate about who's called holder or not but it is alarming that people keeps their money on these exchanges where they shouldn't be or if they should, it must be an amount only that they are using for trading and affordable to lose.

comments.author: freedomgo
comments.body: We can still call ourselves HODLers even if our holdings are on an exchange. The concept is simply about being willing to hold for the long term, so even if it's on an exchange, it's still ours. The only difference is that we don’t own the private keys, which is a bit risky. What you’re explaining is just the technical side of it, but the essence of holding is there, so yeah, you’re still a HODLer.

comments.author: SatoPrincess
comments.body: Quote from: Odusko on March 06, 2025, 10:41:17 PMYou have full control of your coins on exchange as long as your contract with the exchange still exists and the exchange is in service,No you don’t. Having full control of one’s coins means you own the keys. Centralized exchanges do not give keys nor seed phrase to their users instead all you get is a password and username. Storing your coins on exchanges simply means that you’re trusting a third party with control of your coins.

comments.author: passwordnow
comments.body: That logically makes sense. But the matter to me is not who's going to be called holders or not. And that's how much you're holding. Because matured holders and have got a lot which is their lifesavings, the majority won't be putting it on any exchanges unless they have some plans to dump it and convert it into stable coins. There are holders, a someone who's got a lot of holdings in exchanges but less to none in noncustodial wallets. But there goes the little holders that they've got in their noncustodial wallets and rarely use the exchanges and never have plans to accumulate more. There is so much to describe with each of us. But we are all meeting in the middle of this, we're all part of this community and we love holding but not mostly sitting our funds in exchanges.

comments.author: EFS
comments.body: In the past 15 years we've seen so many exchanges open and shut down that there's nothing more insecure than keeping coins on an exchange. Those who hold their coins on exchanges aren't really hodlers, maybe we can call them forgetful. Even the biggest exchanges have either pulled exit scams, been forced to shut down due to legal issues or lost users' funds to hacks. Never trust any exchange. Always keep your Bitcoin in your own wallet.

comments.author: Adbitco
comments.body: Why on earth would people go hold bitcoin on centralized exchange?For the time being, any coin on centralized exchange is not your coin, you can have access to that exchange but if there are any hack you wouldn't be skipped and you would be affected at this point you are not holdler, like what few people already said. To have full control over your coin and to be a full holder you need to move out your funds from exchange to none-costudial wallet. Buy coin, hold for long term and move out your funds from centralized exchange then you are a holder.
